As Chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I have made gun violence prevention one of our top priorities, holding four hearings thus far. With at least 244 mass shootings already this year, I am well aware how far we have to go when it comes to solving the gun violence epidemic.

I support President Biden’s administrative actions, including a rule to help stop the proliferation of untraceable ghost guns. We must also address the root causes of gun violence, including trauma, and fund community violence intervention programs.
The Senate must take action on common-sense, constitutional measures that help reduce deadly shootings—like universal background checks—and confirm ATF Director nominee David Chipman.

RT @LeaderHoyer .@GovLarryHogan’s decision to end enhanced unemployment benefits will not only harm struggling families in #MD05, but also hurt MD’s economy. According to @JECDems, this will cost our economy in MD $877 million. I urge the Governor to reverse this decision.https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/a1bd760f-ca79-4e11-ba67-cd2e402e1b5f/2-pager-on-fpuc-and-gop-govs-06.03.2021-final.pdf

Today’s report shows that the economy is continuing to grow.

We have the fiscal capacity to meet this challenge and ensure our economy is more prosperous and equitable in the years to come.
We must also ensure that the recovery is felt equitably among those who have been hardest hit by the pandemic—namely Black and Hispanic communities.

While we celebrate strong job growth and falling unemployment, it’s important to recognize that the work we have left to do will require renewed investments in our labor force and their skills to finish the recovery.

But within this group, an elevated percentage have been out of work for 52 weeks or more.  These workers need continued support. Extended UI and investments in our workforce will be needed to reemploy those hardest hit by the pandemic recession.

Another key issue is long-term unemployment.  

The number of long-term unemployed (27 or more weeks) is dropping, with this number down by 431K from the previous month—this is particularly good news.

.@JECDems recently released a brief outlining how this is not the time to rip the rug out from those who need help the most.  

We estimate that local economies could lose over $13 billion if states proceed with their plans to end enhanced UI benefits. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/03/ending-federal-unemployment-benefits-early-will-costs-states-billions.html

History suggests that these workers will need more assistance to reenter employment, since they don’t have a specific job and employer to return to, and they may have to change occupations or sectors.

Unfortunately, the number of permanently laid off workers climbed steadily over the course of last year as well.  

Although it has declined somewhat, it remains stubbornly elevated.

So let’s take a deeper look at a few key elements in today’s report:  

Last year’s gigantic spike in unemployment was largely composed of temporary layoffs, and those workers continue to be recalled to work at a rapid rate. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3DdNRHXoAAoJlk.jpg

According to the report, the unemployment rate was 9.1% for Black workers, 7.3% for Hispanic workers, 5.5% for Asian workers and 5.1% for white workers. Communities of color were among the hardest hit during the pandemic, and their recovery remains uneven. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3DdIiNXEAsVPyh.jpg

In May, 292K jobs were added in leisure and hospitality, likely a result of continued reopenings and increased vaccination rates. This continues a trend of strong growth, with 328K jobs gained in April and 227K in March. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3DdFP3XIAIyrxI.jpg

The economy has added back nearly 15M jobs—or 66% of those lost—since the peak of the pandemic. 

We are experiencing a record economic recovery with record job growth as the administration continues to provide a path forward to get our economy back up and running. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3DdBuMWQAMdlP-.jpg
